Assignment rules help reduce time to solve a problem by automating the process and ensure that problems are routed to the correct problem-solving team. You can create assignment rules to route problems to specific teams according to information captured in the problem records.

true false true After a problem is reported, assign it to an appropriate group automatically to ensure that it is handled promptly. A problem can be assigned to a problem-solving group based on the configuration item (CI), categorization, and other rules defined in the system.

Once a problem coordinator selects a problem, they manage the problem throughout its lifecycle and they create and coordinate problem tasks if they need help solving the problem.

The coordinator determines whether there is enough information to confirm that it is a valid problem. The coordinator can also choose to cancel the problem, or mark the problem as a duplicate of another problem. If there is not enough information, the coordinator requests information from the user who created the problem. The coordinator also refers to the record that first reported the problem or related incidents to gather additional information.

The coordinator provides a workaround if possible. If any fix is identified, the coordinator suggests a fix as well as documents the cause of the problem. If a fix cannot be identified, the coordinator can choose to accept the risk of currently not fixing this problem.

The coordinator can choose to communicate when a workaround or fix is available for the problem. The incident management process can decide to apply the workaround or the fix or to notify the agent who is assigned to the incident.

The coordinator can create a Known Error article to help with incident deflection. The users, who want to log an incident for an issue, can read the Known Error article and know that there is a workaround for the problem.
